/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s1.title: Purposes
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s1.content:
The main purposes of this Act are— 
 (a) to re-enact and extend the law relating to 
equal opportunity and protection against 
discrimination, sexual harassment and 
victimisation; and 
 (b) to amend the Racial and Religious 
Tolerance Act 2001 in relation to dispute 
resolution; and 
 (c) to make consequential amendments to the 
Racial and Religious Tolerance Act 2001, 
the Victorian Civil and Administrative 
Tribunal Act 1998 and other Acts.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s1/a.content: to re-enact and extend the law relating to The main purposes of this Act are— equal opportunity and protection against discrimination, sexual harassment and victimisation; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s1/b.content: to amend the Racial and Religious Tolerance Act 2001 in relation to dispute resolution; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s1/c.content: to make consequential amendments to the Racial and Religious Tolerance Act 2001, the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998 and other Acts.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s3/a.content: to eliminate discrimination, sexual The objectives of this Act are— harassment and victimisation, to the greatest possible extent;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s3/b.content: to further promote and protect the right to equality set out in the Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s3/c.content: to encourage the identification and elimination of systemic causes of discrimination, sexual harassment and victimisation;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s3/d.content: to promote and facilitate the progressive realisation of equality, as far as reasonably practicable, by recognising that— (i) discrimination can cause social and economic disadvantage and that access to opportunities is not equitably distributed throughout society; (ii) equal application of a rule to different groups can have unequal results or outcomes; (iii) the achievement of substantive equality may require the making of reasonable adjustments and reasonable accommodation and the taking of special measures;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s3/e.content: to enable the Victorian Equal Opportunity and Human Rights Commission to encourage best practice and facilitate compliance with this Act by undertaking

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/1/a.content: direct or indirect discrimination on the basis of an attribute; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/2.content: Discrimination on the basis of an attribute includes discrimination on the basis—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/2/a.content: that a person has that attribute or had it at any time, whether or not he or she had it at the time of the discrimination;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/2/b.content: of a characteristic that a person with that attribute generally has;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/2/c.content: of a characteristic that is generally imputed to a person with that attribute;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/2/d.content: that a person is presumed to have that attribute or to have had it at any time.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/3.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), if a person with a disability is accompanied by or possesses an assistance aid, being accompanied by or the possession of that assistance aid is taken to be a characteristic that a person with that attribute generally has. inserted by No. 81/2014 s. 7. inserted by No. 13/2021 s. 28. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 2.2).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/4.content: In subsection (3)— Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 21 assistance aid means any of the following that alleviates the effects of a person's disability—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/4/a.content: equipment (including a palliative or therapeutic device);

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s7/4/b.content: a person who provides assistance or services to a person with a disability; Examples 1 an interpreter; 2 a reader.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s8/1.content: Direct discrimination occurs if a person treats, or proposes to treat, a person with an attribute unfavourably because of that attribute. Examples 1 An employer advises an employee that she will not be trained to work on new machinery because she is too old to learn new skills.  The employer has discriminated against the employee by denying her training in her employment on the basis of her age. 2 A real estate agent refuses an African man's application for a lease.  The real estate agent tells the man that the landlord would prefer an Australian tenant.  The real estate agent has discriminated against the man by denying him accommodation on the basis of his race.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s8/2.content: In determining whether a person directly discriminates it is irrelevant—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s8/2/a.content: whether or not that person is aware of the discrimination or considers the treatment to be unfavourable;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s8/2/b.content: whether or not the attribute is the only or dominant reason for the treatment, provided that it is a substantial reason. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. items 2.2, 2.3).

Examples 
1 A store requires customers to produce photographic 
identification in the form of a driver's licence before

2 An advertisement for a job as a cleaner requires an applicant

not be reasonable if speaking and reading English fluently is 
not necessary to perform the job.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/1.content: Indirect discrimination occurs if a person imposes, or proposes to impose, a requirement, condition or practice—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/1/a.content: that has, or is likely to have, the effect of disadvantaging persons with an attribute; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/2.content: The person who imposes, or proposes to impose, the requirement, condition or practice has the burden of proving that the requirement, condition or practice is reasonable.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3.content: Whether a requirement, condition or practice is reasonable depends on all the relevant circumstances of the case, including the following—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3/a.content: the nature and extent of the disadvantage resulting from the imposition, or proposed imposition, of the requirement, condition or practice;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3/b.content: whether the disadvantage is proportionate to the result sought by the person who imposes, or proposes to impose, the requirement, condition or practice;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3/c.content: the cost of any alternative requirement, condition or practice;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3/d.content: the financial circumstances of the person imposing, or proposing to impose, the requirement, condition or practice;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/3/e.content: whether reasonable adjustments or reasonable accommodation could be made to the requirement, condition or practice to reduce the disadvantage caused, including the availability of an alternative requirement, condition or practice that would achieve the result sought by the person imposing, or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s9/4.content: In determining whether a person indirectly Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 23 proposing to impose, the requirement, condition or practice but would result in less disadvantage. discriminates it is irrelevant whether or not that person is aware of the discrimination. Examples 1 A store requires customers to produce photographic identification in the form of a driver's licence before collecting an order.  This may disadvantage a person with a visual impairment who is not eligible to hold a driver's licence.  The store's requirement may not be reasonable if the person with a visual impairment can provide an alternative form of photographic identification. 2 An advertisement for a job as a cleaner requires an applicant to speak and read English fluently.  This may disadvantage a person on the basis of his or her race.  The requirement may not be reasonable if speaking and reading English fluently is not necessary to perform the job.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s10.content:
In determining whether or not a person 
discriminates, the person's motive is irrelevant.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/1.content: A person may take a special measure for the purpose of promoting or realising substantive equality for members of a group with a particular attribute.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/2.content: A person does not discriminate against another Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 24 Examples  A company operates in an industry in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are under-represented. The company develops a training program to increase employment opportunities in the company for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. 2 A swimming pool that is located in an area with a significant Muslim population holds women-only swimming sessions to enable Muslim women who cannot swim in mixed company to use the pool. 3 A person establishes a counselling service to provide counselling for gay men and lesbians who are victims of family violence, and whose needs are not met by general family violence counselling services. person by taking a special measure.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/3/c.content: be a proportionate means of achieving the purpose set out in subsection (1); and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/3/d.content: be justified because the members of the group have a particular need for advancement or assistance.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/4.content: A measure is taken for the purpose set out in subsection (1) if it is taken—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/4/b.content: for that purpose as well as other purposes.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/5.content: A person who undertakes a special measure may impose reasonable restrictions on eligibility for the measure.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s12/7.content: On achieving the purpose set out in subsection (1), the measure ceases to be a special measure.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/1.content: This Act does not prohibit discrimination to which a Division of Part 4 applies if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/1/a.content: an exception in that Division applies; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/1/b.content: the conduct constituting discrimination under that Division also constitutes discrimination under another Division of Part 4 and an exception in the other Division applies; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/1/c.content: a general exception under Part 5 applies; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/1/d.content: an exemption under Part 5 applies. Example A football club refuses to register a 15-year-old girl to participate in a football competition that is restricted to boys only.  Section 72 contains an exception from discrimination on grounds of sex in relation to competitive sporting activity.  If that applies to the competition, the club's refusal to register the girl will not be unlawful, regardless of whether any dispute about the refusal is brought as a dispute about discrimination in sport (Division 7), discrimination by a club (Division 6) or discrimination in the provision of services (Division 4).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s13/2.content: An exception or an exemption referred to in subsection (1) is a defence to discrimination, and the person seeking to rely on the exception or exemption has the burden of proving that it applies.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s14.title: Purpose of Part
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s14.content:
The purpose of this Part is to provide for the 
taking of positive action to eliminate 
discrimination, sexual harassment and 
victimisation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15.title: Duty to eliminate discrimination, sexual harassment

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/1.content: This section applies to a person who has a duty or victimisation under Part 4, 6 or 7 not to engage in discrimination, sexual harassment or victimisation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/2.content: A person must take reasonable and proportionate measures to eliminate that discrimination, sexual harassment or victimisation as far as possible.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/3.content: Part 8 does not apply to a contravention of the duty imposed by subsection (2).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/4.content: A contravention of the duty imposed by subsection (2) may be the subject of an investigation undertaken by the Commission under Part 9.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/5.content: The duty imposed by subsection (2) is in addition to—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/5/a.content: a duty under Part 4, 6 or 7; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/5/b.content: in the case of a person who is a public authority, a duty under section 38 of the Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 6.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/6.content: In determining whether a measure is reasonable victimisation Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 27 and proportionate the following factors must be considered—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/6/a.content: the size of the person's business or operations;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/6/b.content: the nature and circumstances of the person's business or operations;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/6/d.content: the person's business and operational priorities;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s15/6/e.content: the practicability and the cost of the measures. Examples 1 A small, not-for-profit community organisation takes steps to ensure that its staff are aware of the organisation's commitment to treating staff with dignity, fairness and respect and makes a clear statement about how complaints from staff will be managed. 2 A large company undertakes an assessment of its compliance with this Act.  As a result of the assessment, the company develops a compliance strategy that includes regular monitoring and provides for continuous improvement of the strategy.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s16.title: Discrimination against job applicants
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s16.content:
An employer must not discriminate against a 
person— 
 (a) in determining who should be offered 
employment; or

to the person; or 
 (c) by refusing or deliberately omitting to offer 
employment to the person; or 
 (d) by denying the person access to a guidance 
program, an apprenticeship training program 
or other occupational training or retraining 
program.

 (h) the consequences for the employee of not 
making such accommodation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/1.content: An employer must not, in relation to the work responsibilities as parent or carer arrangements of an employee, unreasonably refuse to accommodate the responsibilities that the employee has as a parent or carer. Example An employer may be able to accommodate an employee's responsibilities as a parent or carer by allowing the employee to work from home on a Wednesday morning or have a later start time on a Wednesday or, if the employee works on a part-time basis, by rescheduling a regular staff meeting so that the employee can attend.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/2.content: In determining whether an employer unreasonably refuses to accommodate the responsibilities that an employee has as a parent or carer, all relevant facts and circumstances must be considered, including—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/2/a.content: the employee's circumstances, including the nature of his or her responsibilities as a parent or carer; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/2/b.content: the nature of the employee's role; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/2/c.content: the nature of the arrangements required to accommodate those responsibilities; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/2/d.content: the financial circumstances of the employer; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/e.content: the size and nature of the workplace and the Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 31 employer's business; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/f.content: the effect on the workplace and the employer's business of accommodating those responsibilities, including— (i) the financial impact of doing so; (ii) the number of persons who would benefit from or be disadvantaged by doing so; (iii) the impact on efficiency and productivity and, if applicable, on customer service of doing so; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/g.content: the consequences for the employer of making such accommodation; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s19/h.content: the consequences for the employee of not making such accommodation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s24/1.content: An employer may discriminate in determining who should be offered employment in relation to the provision of domestic or personal services (including the care, instruction or supervision of children)—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s24/1/b.content: if the employer is in the business of providing domestic or personal services to others, in the home of the person to whom those services are provided if the discrimination is requested by or on behalf of that person. Example An agency employs people to provide personal care services.  A woman contacts the agency and requests that it provide a carer to assist her with personal care in her home. The woman tells the agency that the carer must be female. The agency may discriminate in determining who should be employed to provide personal care to the woman as the services will be provided in the woman's home, and she has specifically asked for a female carer.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s24/2.content: To avoid doubt, this section applies whether or not the employer is acting personally or through an agent in determining who should be employed.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25.title: Exception—care of children
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25.content:
(1) Nothing in section 16 or 18 applies to 
discrimination by an employer against a person or 
employee if— 
 (a) the employment involves the care, 
instruction or supervision of children; and 
 (b) the discrimination is reasonably necessary to 
protect the physical, psychological or 
emotional wellbeing of the children. 
 (2) Subsection (1) does not apply to employment by a 
post-secondary education provider (within the 
meaning of the Education and Training Reform 
Act 2006).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25/1.content: Nothing in section 16 or 18 applies to discrimination by an employer against a person or employee if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25/1/a.content: the employment involves the care, instruction or supervision of children; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25/1/b.content: the discrimination is reasonably necessary to protect the physical, psychological or emotional wellbeing of the children.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s25/2.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to employment by a post-secondary education provider (within the meaning of the Education and Training Reform Act 2006).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/1.content: An employer may limit the offering of employment to people of one sex if it is a genuine occupational requirement of the employment that the employees be people of that sex.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/2.content: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), it is a genuine occupational requirement to be a person of a particular sex in relation to employment if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/2/a.content: the employment can be performed only by a person having particular physical characteristics (other than strength or stamina) that are possessed only by people of that sex; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/2/b.content: the employment needs to be performed by a person of that sex to preserve decency or privacy because it involves the fitting of clothing for people of that sex; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/2/c.content: the employment includes the conduct of searches of the clothing or bodies of people of that sex; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/d.content: the employee will be required to enter a Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 41 lavatory ordinarily used by people of that sex while it is in use by people of that sex; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/e.content: the employee will be required to enter areas ordinarily used only by people of that sex while those people are in a state of undress.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/3.content: An employer may limit the offering of employment in relation to a dramatic or an artistic performance, entertainment, photographic or modelling work or any other employment—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/3/a.content: to people of a particular age, sex or race;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/3/b.content: to people with or without a particular disability— if it is necessary to do so for reasons of authenticity or credibility.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/4.content: An employer may discriminate on the basis of physical features in the offering of employment in relation to a dramatic or an artistic performance, photographic or modelling work or any similar employment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s26/5.content: An employer may discriminate on the basis of a person's profession, trade or occupation in relation to the offering of employment if experience in a particular profession, trade or occupation is relevant to the employment or offer and is a genuine occupational requirement for the position or role on offer and it is reasonable to discriminate on that basis in the circumstances.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s28.title: Exception—welfare services
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s28.content:
An employer may limit the offering of 
employment to people with a particular attribute 
in relation to the provision of services for people 
with the same attribute if those services— 
 (a) are either— 
 (i) a special measure under section 12; or 
 (ii) a service for special needs under 
section 88; and 
 (b) can be provided most effectively by people 
with that attribute. 
Examples 
1 A service that provides in-home support for people who have 
a mental illness may require that a person who applies for a 
job as a support worker has previously used mental health 
services. 
2 A support service for women who have experienced family 
violence may require that its counsellors are female.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s28A.title: Exception—youth wages
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s28A.content:
An employer may pay an employee who is under 
the age of 21 years according to the employee's 
age.

other person is invited to become a partner if the 
discrimination is reasonable.

Example A firm may be able to accommodate the responsibilities that a person or partner has as a parent or carer by allowing the person or partner to have flexible attendance arrangements.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/2.content: In determining whether a firm unreasonably refuses to accommodate the responsibilities that a person or partner has as a parent or carer, all relevant facts and circumstances must be considered, including—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/2/a.content: the circumstances of the person or partner, including the nature of his or her responsibilities as a parent or carer; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/2/b.content: the nature of the partnership role; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/c.content: the nature of the arrangements required to Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 45 accommodate those responsibilities; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/d.content: the financial circumstances of the firm; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/e.content: the size and nature of the workplace and the firm's business; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/f.content: the effect on the workplace and the firm's business of accommodating those responsibilities, including— (i) the financial impact of doing so; (ii) the number of persons who would benefit from or be disadvantaged by doing so; (iii) the impact on efficiency and productivity and, if applicable, on customer service of doing so; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/g.content: the consequences for the firm of making such accommodation; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s32/h.content: the consequences for the person or partner of not making such accommodation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s33/4.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), in determining whether or not the person or partner could or can adequately perform the genuine and reasonable requirements of partnership in the firm, all the relevant facts and circumstances must be considered, including—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s33/5.content: A firm is not required to make an adjustment under subsection (2) to the extent that the firm has complied with, or has been exempted from compliance with, a relevant disability standard made under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 of the Commonwealth in relation to the subject matter of that adjustment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s33/6.content: A firm is not required to make an adjustment under subsection (2) that relates to a building or land to the extent that— amended by No. 26/2011 s. 9(1)(a). repealed by No. 26/2011 s. 9(1)(b). inserted by No. 26/2011 s. 9(2). inserted by No. 26/2011 s. 9(2).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s36/1.content: A qualifying body must not discriminate against a person—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s37.title: Exception—reasonable terms of qualification
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s37.content:
A qualifying body may set reasonable terms in 
relation to an occupational qualification, or make 
reasonable variations to those terms, to enable a 
person with a disability to practise the profession, 
carry on the trade or business or engage in the 
occupation or employment to which the 
qualification relates. 
Example 
A person is required to complete a certain number of 
hours of supervised clinical practice before he or she 
can qualify as a health professional.  A woman cannot 
do clinical practice because of her disability.  
The qualifying body may dispense with the requirement 
for clinical practice, and restrict the work she is allowed 
to perform under the qualification to teaching and 
research.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s54.title: Discrimination by refusing to allow assistance dogs
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s54.content:
(1) A person must not refuse to provide 
accommodation to a person with a disability 
because that person has an assistance dog. 
 (2) A person must not require, as a term of providing 
accommodation to a person with a disability who 
has an assistance dog— 
 (a) that the dog be kept elsewhere; or 
 (b) that the person pay an extra charge because 
of the dog. 
 (3) This section does not affect the liability of the 
person with the assistance dog for any damage 
caused by the dog.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s54/1.content: A person must not refuse to provide accommodation to a person with a disability because that person has an assistance dog.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s54/2.content: A person must not require, as a term of providing accommodation to a person with a disability who has an assistance dog—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s54/2/a.content: that the dog be kept elsewhere; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58.title: Exception—access to or use of public premises

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/1.content: A person may discriminate against another person unreasonable on the basis of the other person's disability in relation to any premises or facilities in the premises that the public or a section of the public is entitled or allowed to enter or use (whether or not for payment) if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/1/a.content: the person could not reasonably be expected to avoid the discrimination; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/1/b.content: the discrimination is permitted under subsection (3).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/2.content: In determining whether the person could be reasonably expected to avoid the discrimination, all relevant facts and circumstances must be considered, including—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/2/a.content: the circumstances of the person with the disability, including the nature of his or her disability; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/2/b.content: the nature of the measures required to provide or allow access to or use of the premises or facilities in the premises; and substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 13(1). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 3.27).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/c.content: the financial circumstances of the person; Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 67 and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/d.content: the consequences for the person of avoiding the discrimination; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/e.content: the consequences for the person with the disability of the person not avoiding the discrimination. * * * * *

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/3.content: A person may discriminate against another person on the basis of the other person's disability in relation to any premises or facilities in the premises that the public or a section of the public is entitled or allowed to enter or use (whether or not for payment) to the extent that—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/3/a.content: the premises or facilities comply with, or are exempted from compliance with, a relevant disability standard made under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 of the Commonwealth in relation to the subject matter of the discrimination; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58/3/b.content: if the discrimination relates to a building or land on which the  premises or facilities are situated— (i) a determination has been made under section 160B of the Building Act 1993 in relation to that building or land, in relation to the subject matter of discrimination; and (ii) the person complies with the determination. amended by No. 26/2011 ss 13(2)(a), 34(Sch. item 3.27). repealed by No. 26/2011 s. 13(2)(b). inserted by No. 26/2011 s. 13(3).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58A.title: Exception—accommodation unsuitable for children
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s58A.content:
A person may refuse to provide accommodation to 
a child or a person with a child if the premises, 
because of their design or location, are unsuitable 
or inappropriate for occupation by a child.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59.title: Exception—shared accommodation
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59.content:
(1) A person may discriminate in deciding who is to 
occupy residential accommodation— 
 (a) in which the person or a near relative of the 
person lives and intends to continue to live; 
and 
 (b) that is to accommodate no more than 
3 people in addition to a person or the near 
relatives of a person referred to in 
paragraph (a). 
 (2) In this section— 
near relative, in relation to a person, means— 
 (a) a parent or grandparent, child or 
grandchild (whether or not under the 
age of 18) or brother or sister of that 
person; or 
 (b) the spouse or domestic partner of that 
person or of a person referred to in 
paragraph (a).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/1.content: A person may discriminate in deciding who is to occupy residential accommodation—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/1/a.content: in which the person or a near relative of the person lives and intends to continue to live; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/1/b.content: that is to accommodate no more than 3 people in addition to a person or the near relatives of a person referred to in paragraph (a).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/2.content: In this section— near relative, in relation to a person, means—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/2/a.content: a parent or grandparent, child or grandchild (whether or not under the age of 18) or brother or sister of that person; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s59/2/b.content: the spouse or domestic partner of that person or of a person referred to in paragraph (a).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64.title: Discrimination against applicants for membership
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64.content:
A club, or a member of the committee of 
management or other governing body of a club, 
must not discriminate against a person who 
applies for membership of the club— 
 (a) in determining the terms of a particular 
category or type of membership of the club; 
or 
 (b) in the arrangements made for deciding who 
should be offered membership; or 
 (c) by refusing, or failing to accept, the person's 
application for membership; or 
 (d) in the way in which the person's application 
is processed; or 
 (e) in the terms on which the person is admitted 
as a member.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64/a.content: in determining the terms of a particular A club, or a member of the committee of management or other governing body of a club, must not discriminate against a person who applies for membership of the club— category or type of membership of the club; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64/b.content: in the arrangements made for deciding who should be offered membership; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64/c.content: by refusing, or failing to accept, the person's application for membership; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64/d.content: in the way in which the person's application is processed; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s64/e.content: in the terms on which the person is admitted as a member.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s65/a.content: by refusing, or failing to accept, the A club, or a member of the committee of management or other governing body of a club, must not discriminate against a member of the club— member's application for a different category or type of membership; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s65/b.content: by denying or limiting access to any benefit provided by the club; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s65/c.content: by varying the terms of membership; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s65/d.content: by depriving the member of membership; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s65/e.content: by subjecting the member to any other detriment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s66.title: Exception—clubs for minority cultures
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s66.content:
A club, or a member of the committee of 
management or other governing body of a club, 
may exclude from membership a person who is 
not a member of the group of people with an 
attribute for whom the club was established if the 
club operates principally to preserve a minority 
culture.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s66A.title: Exception—clubs for political purposes
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s66A.content:
A club, or a member of the committee of 
management or other governing body of a club, 
may exclude a person from membership on the 
basis of political belief or activity if the club was 
established principally for a political purpose.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s68/1.content: A club, or a member of the committee of management or other governing body of a club, may exclude from membership a person on the basis of that person's sex if membership of the club is available only to persons of the opposite sex. inserted by No. 26/2011 s. 15.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s68/2.content: A club referred to in subsection (1) must make its Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 72 rules of eligibility for membership publicly available, without charge.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69.title: Exception—separate access to benefits for men and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/1.content: A club, or a member of the committee of women management or other governing body of a club, may limit a member's access to a benefit on the basis of the member's sex if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/1/a.content: it is not practicable for men and women to enjoy the benefit at the same time; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/1/b.content: either— (i) access to the same or an equivalent benefit is provided for men and women separately; or (ii) men and women are each entitled to a reasonably equivalent opportunity to enjoy the benefit.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2.content: In determining any matter relating to the application of subsection (1), the following must be considered—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2/a.content: the purposes for which the club is established;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2/b.content: the membership of the club, including any class or type of membership;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2/c.content: the nature of the benefits provided by the club;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2/d.content: the opportunities for the use and enjoyment of those benefits by men and women;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s69/2/e.content: any other relevant circumstances. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 16 (ILA s. 39B(1)). inserted by No. 26/2011 s. 16.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s70.title: Definitions
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s70.content:
In this Division— 
competitive sporting activity includes any 
exhibition or demonstration of a sport, but 
does not include—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s73.title: Discrimination by councillors
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s73.content:

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85.title: Legal incapacity and age of majority
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85.content:
(1) Nothing in this Act is intended to affect the law in 
relation to the legal capacity or incapacity of any 
person or the age of majority. 
 (2) A person may discriminate against another person 
if— 
 (a) the other person is subject to a legal 
incapacity because of his or her age or 
disability; and 
 (b) the incapacity is relevant to the transaction or 
activity in which they are involved. 
Example 
A service provider may refuse to enter into a contract with a 
child who, because of his or her age, does not have legal 
capacity to enter the contract.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85/1.content: Nothing in this Act is intended to affect the law in relation to the legal capacity or incapacity of any person or the age of majority.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85/2.content: A person may discriminate against another person if—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85/2/a.content: the other person is subject to a legal incapacity because of his or her age or disability; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s85/2/b.content: the incapacity is relevant to the transaction or activity in which they are involved. Example A service provider may refuse to enter into a contract with a child who, because of his or her age, does not have legal capacity to enter the contract.

discrimination

85

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s86/1.content: A person may discriminate against another person on the basis of disability or physical features if the discrimination is reasonably necessary—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s86/1/a.content: to protect the health or safety of any person (including the person discriminated against) or of the public generally; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s86/1/b.content: to protect the property of any person (including the person discriminated against) or any public property.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s86/2.content: A person may discriminate against another person on the basis of pregnancy if the discrimination is reasonably necessary to protect the health or safety of any person (including the person discriminated against). repealed by No. 56/2021 s. 9. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 4.2). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 4.3).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s87.title: Age benefits and concessions
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s87.content:
A person may provide benefits, including 
concessions, to another person based on age.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88.title: Special needs
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88.content:
(1) A person may establish special services, benefits 
or facilities that meet the special needs of people 
with a particular attribute and may limit eligibility 
for such services to people with the particular 
attribute. 
Example 
A community organisation establishes a support group for 
single fathers in response to research that shows that single 
fathers have a need for targeted counselling and support. 
 (2) A person does not discriminate by establishing 
special services, benefits or facilities, or by 
limiting eligibility for such services in accordance 
with subsection (1). 
 (3) Without limiting the generality of 
subsection (1)— 
 (a) a person may grant a woman any right, 
privilege or benefit in relation to pregnancy 
or childbirth; 
 (b) a person may provide, or restrict the offering 
of, holiday tours to people of a particular age 
or age group.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88/1.content: A person may establish special services, benefits or facilities that meet the special needs of people with a particular attribute and may limit eligibility for such services to people with the particular attribute. Example A community organisation establishes a support group for single fathers in response to research that shows that single fathers have a need for targeted counselling and support.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88/2.content: A person does not discriminate by establishing special services, benefits or facilities, or by limiting eligibility for such services in accordance with subsection (1).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88/3.content: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1)—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88/3/a.content: a person may grant a woman any right, privilege or benefit in relation to pregnancy or childbirth;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s88/3/b.content: a person may provide, or restrict the offering of, holiday tours to people of a particular age or age group.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s91.title: Applicant to give notice to Commission

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92.title: What is sexual harassment?
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92.content:
(1) For the purpose of this Act, a person sexually 
harasses another person if he or she— 
 (a) makes an unwelcome sexual advance, or an 
unwelcome request for sexual favours, to the 
other person; or 
 (b) engages in any other unwelcome conduct of 
a sexual nature in relation to the other 
person— 
in circumstances in which a reasonable person, 
having regard to all the circumstances, would 
have anticipated that the other person would be 
offended, humiliated or intimidated. 
 (2) In subsection (1) conduct of a sexual nature 
includes— 
 (a) subjecting a person to any act of physical 
intimacy; 
 (b) making, orally or in writing, any remark or 
statement with sexual connotations to a 
person or about a person in his or her 
presence; 
 (c) making any gesture, action or comment of a 
sexual nature in a person's presence.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/1.content: For the purpose of this Act, a person sexually harasses another person if he or she—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/1/a.content: makes an unwelcome sexual advance, or an unwelcome request for sexual favours, to the other person; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/1/b.content: engages in any other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the other person— in circumstances in which a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the other person would be offended, humiliated or intimidated.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/2.content: In subsection (1) conduct of a sexual nature includes—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/2/a.content: subjecting a person to any act of physical intimacy;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/2/b.content: making, orally or in writing, any remark or statement with sexual connotations to a person or about a person in his or her presence;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s92/2/c.content: making any gesture, action or comment of a sexual nature in a person's presence.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94.title: Harassment in common workplaces
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94.content:
(1) A person must not sexually harass another person 
at a place that is a workplace of both of them. 
 (2) For the purposes of this section it is irrelevant— 
 (a) whether each person is an employer, an 
employee or neither; and 
 (b) if they are employees, whether their 
employers are the same or different. 
 (3) In this section workplace means any place where 
a person attends for the purpose of carrying out 
any functions in relation to his or her employment, 
occupation, business, trade or profession and need 
not be a person's principal place of business or 
employment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94/1.content: A person must not sexually harass another person at a place that is a workplace of both of them.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94/2.content: For the purposes of this section it is irrelevant—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94/2/a.content: whether each person is an employer, an employee or neither; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94/2/b.content: if they are employees, whether their employers are the same or different.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s94/3.content: In this section workplace means any place where a person attends for the purpose of carrying out any functions in relation to his or her employment, occupation, business, trade or profession and need not be a person's principal place of business or employment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s96.content:

sexually harass— 
 (a) a person seeking to become a member of that 
organisation; or 
 (b) another member of that organisation; or 
 (c) an employee of that organisation. 
 (2) An employee of an industrial organisation must 
not sexually harass— 
 (a) a person seeking to become a member of that 
organisation; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s96/1.content: A member of an industrial organisation must not sexually harass—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97.title: Harassment by members of qualifying bodies

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/1.content: A member of a qualifying body must not sexually harass—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/1/a.content: a person seeking action in connection with an occupational qualification; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/1/b.content: another member of that qualifying body; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/1/c.content: an employee of that qualifying body.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/2.content: An employee of a qualifying body must not sexually harass—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/2/a.content: a person seeking action in connection with an occupational qualification; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/2/b.content: a member of that qualifying body.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s97/3.content: In this section action in connection with an occupational qualification means conferring, renewing, extending, revoking or withdrawing an occupational qualification.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98.title: Harassment in educational institutions
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98.content:
(1) An employee of an educational institution must 
not sexually harass— 
 (a) a person seeking admission to that institution 
as a student; or  
 (b) a student at that institution. 
 (2) A student at an educational institution must not 
sexually harass— 
 (a) another student at that institution; or 
 (b) an employee of that institution; or 
 (c) a member of the educational authority 
administering that institution. 
 (3) A member of an educational authority must not 
sexually harass— 
 (a) a person seeking admission to the institution 
administered by the authority as a student; or 
 (b) a student at that institution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/1.content: An employee of an educational institution must not sexually harass—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/1/a.content: a person seeking admission to that institution as a student; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/2/a.content: another student at that institution; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/2/b.content: an employee of that institution; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/2/c.content: a member of the educational authority administering that institution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/3.content: A member of an educational authority must not sexually harass—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s98/3/a.content: a person seeking admission to the institution administered by the authority as a student; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s99.title: Harassment in the provision of goods and services
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s99.content:
(1) A person must not sexually harass another person 
in the course of providing, or offering to provide, 
goods or services to that other person. 
 (2) A person must not sexually harass another person 
in the course of receiving or selecting goods or 
services provided by that other person. 
 (3) This section applies whether or not the goods or 
services are provided or received for payment.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s99/1.content: A person must not sexually harass another person in the course of providing, or offering to provide, goods or services to that other person.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s99/2.content: A person must not sexually harass another person in the course of receiving or selecting goods or services provided by that other person.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s99/3.content: This section applies whether or not the goods or services are provided or received for payment.

A member of a club, including a member of the 
committee of management or other governing 
body of the club, must not sexually harass— 
 (a) a person seeking to become a member of the 
club; or 
 (b) another member of the club; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s103.title: Prohibition of victimisation
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s103.content: A person must not victimise another person.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1.content: A person victimises another person if the person subjects or threatens to subject the other person to any detriment because the other person, or a person associated with the other person—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/a.content: has brought a dispute to the Commission for dispute resolution; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/b.content: has made a complaint against any person under the old Act; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/c.content: has brought any other proceedings under this Act or the old Act against any person; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/d.content: has given evidence or information, or produced a document, in connection with— (i) any proceedings under this Act or the old Act; or (ii) any investigation conducted by the Commission; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/e.content: has attended a compulsory conference or mediation at the Tribunal in any proceedings under this Act or the old Act; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/1/f.content: has otherwise done anything in accordance with this Act or the old Act in relation to any person; or amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 5.1). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 20.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/g.content: has alleged that any person has contravened Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 94 a provision of Part 4 or 6 or this Part, or Part 3, 5 or 6 of the old Act, unless the allegation is false and was not made in good faith; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/h.content: has refused to do anything that— (i) would contravene a provision of Part 4 or 6 or this Part; or (ii) would have contravened a provision of Part 3, 5 or 6 of the old Act— or because the person believes that the other person or the associate has done or intends to do any of those things.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/2.content: It is sufficient for subsection (1)(g) that the allegation states the act or omission that would constitute the contravention without actually stating that this Act, or a provision of this Act, has been contravened.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/3.content: In determining whether a person victimises another person it is irrelevant—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/3/a.content: whether or not a factor in subsection (1) is the only or dominant reason for the treatment or threatened treatment provided that it is a substantial reason;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/3/b.content: whether the person acts alone or in association with any other person.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s104/4.content: In this section, old Act means the Equal Opportunity Act 1995, as in force before its repeal.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115.title: Beginning and end of dispute resolution
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115.content:
(1) Dispute resolution starts when the person bringing 
the dispute informs the Commission that he or she 
wishes to proceed with dispute resolution. 
 (2) Dispute resolution ends when the earliest of the 
following occurs— 
 (a) the Commission declines to provide or to 
continue to provide dispute resolution under 
section 116; 
 (b) a party withdraws from dispute resolution 
under section 118; 
 (c) the parties to the dispute reach agreement 
about the subject matter of the dispute.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115/1.content: Dispute resolution starts when the person bringing the dispute informs the Commission that he or she wishes to proceed with dispute resolution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115/2.content: Dispute resolution ends when the earliest of the following occurs—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115/2/a.content: the Commission declines to provide or to continue to provide dispute resolution under section 116;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115/2/b.content: a party withdraws from dispute resolution under section 118;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s115/2/c.content: the parties to the dispute reach agreement about the subject matter of the dispute.

provide or to continue to provide dispute 
resolution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s116/a.content: the alleged contravention occurred more than resolution The Commission may decline to provide or to continue to provide dispute resolution for any of the following reasons— 12 months before the dispute was brought; amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.11). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.11). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.12).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s116/b.content: the matter has been adequately dealt with by Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 102 a court or tribunal;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s116/c.content: the matter involves subject matter that would be more appropriately dealt with by a court or tribunal;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s116/d.content: a person has initiated proceedings in another forum;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s116/e.content: having regard to all the circumstances, the Commission considers it is not appropriate to provide or to continue to provide dispute resolution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s117.title: Admissibility of information gathered during
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s117.content:
dispute resolution 
 (1) Evidence of anything said or done in the course of 
dispute resolution is inadmissible in proceedings 
before the Tribunal or any other legal proceeding 
relating to the subject matter of the dispute. 
 (2) This section applies despite section 131 of the 
Evidence Act 2008.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s117/1.content: Evidence of anything said or done in the course of dispute resolution dispute resolution is inadmissible in proceedings before the Tribunal or any other legal proceeding relating to the subject matter of the dispute.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s117/2.content: This section applies despite section 131 of the Evidence Act 2008.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s118.title: Withdrawal from dispute resolution
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s118.content:
(1) A party to a dispute may withdraw from dispute 
resolution at any time by informing the 
Commission that the party no longer wishes to 
participate in the dispute resolution. 
 (2) Withdrawal from dispute resolution does not 
prevent a person making an application to the 
Tribunal under this Act or commencing 
proceedings in another jurisdiction.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s118/1.content: A party to a dispute may withdraw from dispute resolution at any time by informing the Commission that the party no longer wishes to participate in the dispute resolution.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s118/2.content: Withdrawal from dispute resolution does not prevent a person making an application to the Tribunal under this Act or commencing proceedings in another jurisdiction.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/1.content: This section applies if, following dispute resolution, the parties to the dispute reach agreement with respect to the subject matter of the dispute. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.12). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.13).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/2.content: Any party may request that a written record of Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 103 agreement be prepared by the parties or the Commission.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/3.content: A request must be made within 30 days after the agreement is reached.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/4.content: If a record of agreement is prepared by the Commission following a request under subsection (2)—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/4/a.content: the record must be signed by or on behalf of each party; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/4/b.content: the Commission must certify the record of agreement.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/5.content: If a record of agreement is prepared by the parties following a request under subsection (2)—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/5/a.content: the record must be signed by or on behalf of each party; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/5/b.content: on the request of a party, the Commission may certify the record of agreement.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/6.content: If the Commission certifies the record of agreement under subsection (4)(b) or (5)(b), the Commission must give each party a copy of the signed and certified record.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s119/7.content: The refusal of the Commission to certify the record of agreement does not affect the validity of the agreement. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.14).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120.title: Registration of settlement agreements
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120.content:
(1) Any party, after notifying the other party in 
writing, may lodge a copy of the signed and 
certified record of agreement with the Tribunal for 
registration. 
 (2) Subject to subsection (3), the Tribunal must 
register the agreement and give a certified copy of 
the registered record to each party. 
 (3) If the Tribunal, constituted by a presidential 
member, considers that it may not be practicable 
to enforce, or to supervise compliance with, an 
agreement or part of an agreement the Tribunal— 
 (a) in the case of an agreement, may refuse to 
register the record of agreement; or 
 (b) in the case of part of an agreement, may 
refuse to register the part of the record of 
agreement that it considers may not be 
practicable to enforce, or to supervise 
compliance with. 
 (4) On registration, the registered agreement or 
registered part of the agreement must be taken to 
be an order of the Tribunal in accordance with its 
terms and may be enforced accordingly. 
 (5) The refusal of the Tribunal to register the record 
of agreement or any part of the record of 
agreement does not affect the validity of the 
agreement.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/1.content: Any party, after notifying the other party in writing, may lodge a copy of the signed and certified record of agreement with the Tribunal for registration.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/2.content: Subject to subsection (3), the Tribunal must register the agreement and give a certified copy of the registered record to each party.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/3.content: If the Tribunal, constituted by a presidential member, considers that it may not be practicable to enforce, or to supervise compliance with, an agreement or part of an agreement the Tribunal—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/3/a.content: in the case of an agreement, may refuse to register the record of agreement; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/3/b.content: in the case of part of an agreement, may refuse to register the part of the record of agreement that it considers may not be practicable to enforce, or to supervise compliance with.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/4.content: On registration, the registered agreement or registered part of the agreement must be taken to be an order of the Tribunal in accordance with its terms and may be enforced accordingly.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s120/5.content: The refusal of the Tribunal to register the record of agreement or any part of the record of agreement does not affect the validity of the agreement.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121.title: Tribunal may make interim orders to prevent

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/1.content: The Tribunal may make an interim order to prejudice to dispute resolution prevent any party to a dispute from acting in a manner prejudicial to dispute resolution or to any decision or order the Tribunal might subsequently make.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/2.content: An application for an order under subsection (1) Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 105 may be made by—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/2/a.content: a person bringing the dispute to the Commission for dispute resolution; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/3.content: An application may be made at any time before an application under section 122 relating to the dispute has been made to the Tribunal.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/4.content: In making an interim order, the Tribunal must have regard to—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/4/a.content: whether or not the person bringing the dispute has established a prima facie case with respect to the dispute; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/4/b.content: any possible detriment or advantage to the public interest in making the order; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/4/c.content: any possible detriment to the case of the person bringing the dispute if the order is not made.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/5.content: An interim order applies for the period, not exceeding 28 days, specified in it and may be extended from time to time by the Tribunal.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/6.content: The party against whom the interim order is sought is a party to the proceeding on an application under subsection (2).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s121/7.content: Nothing in this section affects or takes away from the Tribunal's power under section 123 of the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998 to make orders of an interim nature in a proceeding in the Tribunal. amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.15). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.15).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s122.title: Application may be made to Tribunal in respect of
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s122.content:
dispute 
A person may make an application to the Tribunal 
in respect of an alleged contravention of Part 4, 6 
or 7, whether or not the person has brought a 
dispute to the Commission for dispute resolution.

Equal Opportunity Act 2010 
No. 16 of 2010 
107

 (i) is entitled to make an application under 
subsection (1)(a); and 
 (ii) has consented to the application being 
made on the person's behalf; and 
 (b) the alleged contravention arises out of the 
same conduct. 
 (3) An authorisation under subsection (1)(b)(i) may 
be given— 
 (a) in writing; or 
 (b) in any other manner approved by the 
Tribunal. 
 (4) It is not necessary for the alleged contravention to 
relate exclusively to the person making the 
application.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/1.content: The following persons may make an application to the Tribunal under section 122—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/1/a.content: a person who claims that another person has contravened a provision of Part 4, 6 or 7 in relation to that person;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/1/b.content: if that person is unable to make an application because of disability— (i) a person authorised by that person to act on his or her behalf; or (ii) if that person is unable to authorise another person, any other person on his or her behalf;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/1/c.content: if that person is a child— (i) the child; or (ii) a parent of the child on the child's behalf; or (iii) if the Tribunal is satisfied that the child or a parent of the child consents, any other person on the child's behalf.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/2.content: A person may make an application on behalf of the person and another person or persons if the Tribunal is satisfied that— amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.16). amended by No. 26/2011 s. 34(Sch. item 6.17).

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/a.content: each person— Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 107 (i) is entitled to make an application under subsection (1)(a); and (ii) has consented to the application being made on the person's behalf; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/b.content: the alleged contravention arises out of the same conduct.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/3.content: An authorisation under subsection (1)(b)(i) may be given—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/3/b.content: in any other manner approved by the Tribunal.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s123/4.content: It is not necessary for the alleged contravention to relate exclusively to the person making the application.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124.title: Representative body may apply to Tribunal
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124.content:

adversely affect the interests of the body or the

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124/1.content: A representative body may make an application to the Tribunal on behalf of a named person or persons if the Tribunal is satisfied that—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124/1/a.content: each person— (i) is entitled to make an application under section 123(1)(a); and (ii) has consented to the application being made by the body on the person's behalf; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124/1/b.content: the representative body has a sufficient interest in the application; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124/1/c.content: if the application is made on behalf of more than one person, the alleged contravention arises out of the same conduct.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s124/2.content: A representative body has sufficient interest in an Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 108 application if the conduct that constitutes the alleged contravention is a matter of genuine concern to the body because of the way conduct of that nature adversely affects or has the potential to adversely affect the interests of the body or the interests or welfare of the persons it represents.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s125/a.content: find that a person has contravened a After hearing the evidence and representations that the parties to an application desire to adduce or make, the Tribunal may— provision of Part 4, 6 or 7 and make any one or more of the following orders— (i) an order that the person refrain from committing any further contravention of this Act; (ii) an order that the person pay to the applicant, within a specified period, an amount the Tribunal thinks fit to compensate the applicant for loss, damage or injury suffered in consequence of the contravention; (iii) an order that the person do anything specified in the order with a view to redressing any loss, damage or injury suffered by the applicant as a result of the contravention; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s125/b.content: find that a person has contravened a provision of Part 4, 6 or 7 but decline to take any further action; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s125/c.content: find that a person has not contravened a provision of Part 4, 6 or 7 and make an order that the application or part of the application be dismissed.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s126.title: Commission may apply to enforce order of Tribunal

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s126/1/a.content: the Tribunal has made an order referred to in section 125(a); and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s126/1/b.content: a person has failed to comply with the order.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s126/2.content: If the applicant consents, the Commission may enforce the order on behalf of the applicant in accordance with section 121(1) or 122(1) of the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998. Note If the Commission enforces the order in accordance with section 121(1) or 122(1) of the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998, the applicant may subsequently enforce that order as an order of the court. See sections 121(3) and 122(3) of the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 1998.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s127/a.content: the matter— The Commission may conduct an investigation into any matter relating to the operation of this Act if— (i) raises an issue that is serious in nature; and (ii) relates to a class or group of persons; and (iii) cannot reasonably be expected to be resolved by dispute resolution or by making an application to the Tribunal under section 122; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s127/b.content: there are reasonable grounds to suspect that one or more contraventions of this Act have occurred; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s127/c.content: the investigation would advance the objectives of this Act. Example An organisation has a policy that indirectly discriminates against persons with a particular attribute.  The Commission has received several calls complaining about this policy and the policy has received media attention.  Although some claims that the policy is discriminatory have been settled on an individual basis, the policy has not been changed. The Commission may decide that, in these circumstances, an investigation could help identify and eliminate a systemic cause of discrimination. Pt 9 (Heading and ss 127– 147) substituted as Pt 9 (Heading and ss 127– 144) by No. 26/2011 s. 21. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s128.title: Matters referred by Tribunal for investigation
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s128.content:
The Tribunal may refer a matter (other than a 
matter that is the subject of proceedings before the 
Tribunal) to the Commission for the Commission 
to consider whether the Commission should 
conduct an investigation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s129.title: Commission to conduct investigation as it thinks fit
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s129.content:
(1) Subject to this Part, the Commission may conduct 
an investigation in the manner it thinks fit. 
 (2) In conducting an investigation the Commission is 
bound by the principles of natural justice, unless 
otherwise expressly provided in this Part.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s129/1.content: Subject to this Part, the Commission may conduct an investigation in the manner it thinks fit.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s129/2.content: In conducting an investigation the Commission is bound by the principles of natural justice, unless otherwise expressly provided in this Part.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s130.title: Commission may ask for information
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s130.content:
If it is reasonably necessary for the purpose of 
conducting an investigation, the Commission may 
ask any party to provide information in relation to 
an investigation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/1.content: The Commission may apply to the Tribunal for an information or documents order requiring a person to provide information or a document or both to the Commission.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/2.content: The Tribunal may make an order referred to in subsection (1) if it is satisfied that—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/2/a.content: a person is in possession of information or a document that is relevant to an investigation; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/2/b.content: the information or document is necessary for the conduct of the investigation. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/3.content: In making an order referred to in subsection (1), Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 112 the Tribunal must have regard to—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/3/a.content: any evidence of the impact that making the order would be likely to have on the person's business or other activities; and

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/3/b.content: the extent of disruption or inconvenience that is likely to be caused to the person if the order were made.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/4.content: In making an order referred to in subsection (1), the Tribunal is not required to consider whether the Commission may conduct the investigation under section 127.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/5.content: An order referred to in subsection (1) must specify that the person must do either or both of the following within a reasonable period specified in the order, or on a reasonable date and at a reasonable time specified in the order—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/5/a.content: give the Commission a document containing information required by the order;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/5/b.content: produce to the Commission the documents specified in the order.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/6.content: The Tribunal may give directions prohibiting the disclosure of the identity of a person or information that would be reasonably likely to identify a person if the Tribunal considers that preservation of the person's anonymity is necessary—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/6/a.content: to protect the person's security of employment, privacy or any right protected by the Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities Act 2006; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/6/b.content: to protect the person from victimisation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s131/7.content: A document referred to in subsection (5)(a) must Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 113 be signed by the person or, if the person is a body corporate, an officer of the body corporate.

ordinarily available to the person and the 
Tribunal considers that—

or inconvenient for the person to 
produce the document.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/1.content: The Commission may give directions prohibiting or limiting the publication of—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/1/a.content: any evidence given before the Commission or any information given to the Commission as part of an investigation; or

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/1/b.content: the contents of any document produced to the Commission as part of an investigation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/2.content: Subsection (1) applies whether or not a person was compelled to give the evidence or produce the information or document under section 131 or 134.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/3.content: In deciding whether or not to give a direction under subsection (1), the Commission must have regard to the need to prevent any of the following as are relevant to the circumstances—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/3/a.content: prejudice to the relations between the Government and the Commonwealth Government or between the Government and the Government of another State or a Territory;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/3/b.content: the disclosure of deliberations or decisions of the Cabinet, or of a Committee of the Cabinet;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/3/c.content: prejudice to the proper functioning of the Government; substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/d.content: the disclosure, or the ascertaining by a Equal Opportunity Act 2010 No. 16 of 2010 117 person, of the existence or identity of a confidential source of information in relation to the enforcement of the criminal law;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/e.content: the endangering of the life or physical safety of any person;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/f.content: prejudice to the proper enforcement of the law or the protection of public safety;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/g.content: the disclosure of information the disclosure of which is prohibited, absolutely or subject to qualifications, by or under another Act;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s136/h.content: the unreasonable disclosure of the personal affairs of any person; (i) the unreasonable disclosure of confidential commercial information.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s137/1.content: The Commission may apply to the Tribunal for an prejudice to investigation interim order to prevent any person from acting in a manner prejudicial to an investigation while the investigation is being conducted.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s137/2.content: In making an interim order, the Tribunal must have regard to any possible detriment or advantage to the public interest in making the order.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s137/3.content: An interim order applies for the period, not exceeding 28 days, specified in it and may be extended from time to time by the Tribunal.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s137/4.content: The person against whom the order is sought is a party to a proceeding on an application under subsection (1). substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s138.title: Investigation when other proceedings commenced
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s138.content:
(1) The Commission may commence or continue to 
conduct an investigation despite the fact that 
proceedings have commenced in any court or 
tribunal that relate to or are otherwise connected 
with the subject matter of the investigation. 
 (2) If the Commission is or becomes aware that 
proceedings referred to in subsection (1) have 
commenced, the Commission must take all 
reasonable steps to ensure that the conduct of the 
investigation does not prejudice those 
proceedings.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s138/1.content: The Commission may commence or continue to conduct an investigation despite the fact that proceedings have commenced in any court or tribunal that relate to or are otherwise connected with the subject matter of the investigation.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s138/2.content: If the Commission is or becomes aware that proceedings referred to in subsection (1) have commenced, the Commission must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the conduct of the investigation does not prejudice those proceedings.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/1.content: After conducting an investigation, the Commission may take any action it thinks fit.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/2.content: Without limiting subsection (1), the Commission may—

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/2/b.content: enter into an agreement with a person about action required to comply with this Act;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/2/c.content: refer a matter to the Tribunal;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/2/d.content: make a report with respect to the matter to the Attorney-General;

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s139/2/e.content: make a report with respect to the matter to the Parliament. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21. substituted by No. 26/2011 s. 21.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s140.title: Registration of agreements
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s140.content:
(1) If— 
 (a) the Commission enters into an agreement 
with a person under section 139(2)(b); and 
 (b) the agreement provides for registration under 
this section— 
any party to that agreement may lodge a copy of 
the signed agreement with the Tribunal for 
registration. 
 (2) Subject to subsection (3), the Tribunal must 
register the agreement and give a certified copy of 
the agreement to each party. 
 (3) If the Tribunal, constituted by a presidential 
member, considers that it may not be practicable 
to enforce, or to supervise compliance with, an 
agreement or part of an agreement the Tribunal— 
 (a) in the case of an agreement, may refuse to 
register the agreement; or 
 (b) in the case of part of an agreement, may 
refuse to register the part of the agreement 
that it considers may not be practicable to 
enforce, or to supervise compliance with. 
 (4) On registration, the registered agreement or 
registered part of the agreement must be taken to 
be an order of the Tribunal in accordance with its 
terms and may be enforced accordingly. 
 (5) The refusal of the Tribunal to register the 
agreement or any part of the agreement does not 
affect the validity of the agreement.

/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s143.title: Content of reports
/au-victoria/eoa/2010/s143.content:
(1) If the Commission believes there are grounds for 
making adverse findings about a person in the 
report of an investigation, the Commission must 
give the person a reasonable opportunity to 
comment on the subject matter of the investigation 
and respond to the grounds for making the adverse 
findings before— 
 (a) providing the report to the Attorney-General 
or the Parliament; or 
 (b) publishing the report. 
 (2) The Commission may exclude from the report any 
matter if it considers it desirable to do so, having 
regard to the factors set out in section 135(2) 
and 136(3). 
 (3) If the Commission provides the report to the 
Attorney-General, the Commission must advise 
the Attorney-General about any matter excluded 
from the report under subsection (2) and the 
reasons for its exclusion.
